dc:description:
The *RPL10* gene, encoding a ribosomal protein, was first suggested to be implicated in X-linked autism in 2006 by Klauk et al. (PMID: 16940977). They reported two C-terminal missense variants in two independent families with two males each with autism spectrum disorder. Although the authors suggested these two variants resulted in hypomorphic alleles with respect to the regulation of the translation process when expressed in yeast, they were not scored as evidence because subsequent rescue studies in zebrafish showed no loss of function (PMID: 25316788). Four other missense variants in *RPL10* have been reported in the literature: 1) Brooks et al. (2014, PMID: 25316788) and Bourque et al. (2018, PMID: 29066376) reported the same N-terminal missense variant (p.Lys78Glu) in affected males from 2 unrelated families. Common clinical features included intellectual disability, seizures, microcephaly, hypotonia, hearing loss, ataxia, dysmorphic facial features, cardiac defects, and short stature. In a zebrafish model with knockdown of rpl10, p.Lys78Glu was not able to rescue the microcephaly phenotype, suggesting a loss of function variant (PMID: 25316788). 2) Another missense variant (p.Gly161Ser) was reported by Thevenon et al. (2015, PMID: 25846674) in a family with 4 males with syndromic intellectual disability. Although this variant has not been functionally validated, a mutation in yeast affecting the same amino acid results in loss of function (PMID: 9933353). 3) Zanni et al. (2015, PMID: 26290468) reported an additional missense variant (p.Ala64Val) in 2 maternal male cousins with syndromic intellectual disability. Although they shared some features with the previously reported patients, notably ataxia, they also exhibited other features not reported previously, such as spondylo-epiphyseal dysplasia. In a yeast model, this variant was shown to exhibit an increase in translationally active ribosomes, unlike previously reported variants. 4) More recently, Cappuccio et al. (2022, PMID: 35876338) reported a recurrent missense variant (p.Arg32Leu) in *RPL10* in 4 male children from 3 unrelated families. In addition to intellectual disability, dysmorphic features, and progressive postnatal microcephaly, the 4 boys had retinal abnormalities. No functional studies were performed, but the recurrence of the variant and the phenotypic overlap with previously reported cases supports a deleterious effect. 

In addition, two further missense variants have been reported in ClinVar: 5) A maternally-inherited missense variant (p.Gly161Asp, Accession: SCV001814517.1 ) in a male with developmental delay, seizure-like activity, microcephaly, hypotonia, growth delay, and dysmorphic features. Functional studies in yeast suggest a damaging effect (PMID: 9933353). A different variant affecting the same amino acid was reported previously in a family with 4 affected individuals (Thevenon et al. 2015, PMID: 25846674). 6) A *de novo* missense variant (p.Arg3His, Accession: SCV000589527.2 ) in a male with intellectual disability, developmental delay, and microcephaly.

This gene-disease relationship is also supported by a zebrafish model with decreased head size, decreased translation activity and increased apoptosis in the brain (PMID: 25316788). 

In summary, there is definitive evidence supporting the relationship between *RPL10* and X-linked syndromic intellectual disability. This classification was approved by the ClinGen Intellectual Disability and Autism Gene Curation Expert Panel on November 28, 2024. This gene-disease pair was originally evaluated in March 2018 and given a Limited classification. It was reevaluated on January 20, 2021 and given a Moderate classification due to changes in scoring practices. As a result of a further reevaluation on November 28, 2024, the classification increased from Moderate to Definitive with the addition of new cases (PMID: 35876338 and ClinVar).

evidence.dc:description: This family has two dizygotic twins with autism and a maternally-inherited p.Leu206Met variant. Functional data in Brooks et al., 2014 (PMID: 25316788) contradicts the pathogenicity of this variant, therefore, this has been downgraded to 0 points. Furthermore, no syndromic features were reported in these two twins, in contrast to the individuals reported by Brooks et al. (2014), Thevenon et al. (2015), and Bourque et al. (2018). Variant is present twice in gnomAD v4.1.0 (2/1212020 alleles, 1 male and 1 female).

Functional analysis in yeast suggested that this RPL10 missense variant was still able to support basic translation functions but conferred hypomorphism with respect to the regulation of the translation process (Klauck et al., 2006, PMID: 16940977). However, subsequent functional studies performed by Brooke et al. (2014, PMID: 25316788) using in vivo complementation in zebrafish showed that, like wild-type human RPL10 mRNA, the Leu206Met variant was able to fully rescue the microcephaly phenotype in morphants.

This family includes a male proband and his affected male cousin. The functional data showed increase in translationally active ribosomes in yeast, rather than loss of function like the missense variant reported by Brooks et al. (2014) and Bourque et al. (2018). Although the 2 male cousins reported by Zanni shared some features with the patients reported by Brooks et al. (2014) and Bourque et al. (2018), notably ataxia and cryptorchidism, they also exhibited other features not reported previously, such as spondylo-epiphyseal dysplasia. Two female carriers had completely skewed X chromosome inactivation.

Using yeast as model system, this variant was shown to generate a functional ribosomal protein, able to complement the translational defects of a conditional lethal mutation of yeast rpl10. However, unlike previously reported mutations, this RPL10 missense results in an increase in the actively translating ribosome population.

This family includes two brothers with autism and maternally-inherited p.His213Gln variant. Functional data reported by Brooks et al., 2014 (PMID: 25316788) contradicts the pathogenicity of this missense variant. No syndromic features were reported in these two siblings, in contrast to the individuals reported by Brooks et al. (2014), Thevenon et al. (2015) and Bourque et al. (2018). Furthermore, the mother exhibited random X chromosome inactivation (Chiocchetti et al., 2011, PMID: 21567917). Additionally, this variant is present in 101/1209747 alleles (0.008%) in gnomAD (v4.1.0), including 21 hemizygous European (non-Finnish) males.

Functional analysis in yeast suggested that this RPL10 missense variant was still able to support basic translation functions but conferred hypomorphism with respect to the regulation of the translation process (Klauck et al., 2006, PMID: 16940977). However, subsequent functional studies performed by Brooke et al. (2014, PMID: 25316788) using in vivo complementation in zebrafish showed that, like wild-type human RPL10 mRNA, the His213Gln variant was able to fully rescue the microcephaly phenotype in morphants.

Another variant affecting the same amino acid (p.Gly161Ser) was reported in a family with 4 affected individuals (Thevenon et al., 2015, PMID: 25846674). Phenotype information provided by laboratory via personal communication.

dc:source.dc:abstract: Not observed in large population cohorts (Lek et al., 2016); Published functional studies suggest a damaging effect (Koller et al., 1996); In silico analysis, which includes protein predictors and evolutionary conservation, supports a deleterious effect; This variant is associated with the following publications: (PMID: 8789260)
dc:source.dc:creator: GeneDx
dc:source.dc:title: NM_006013.5(RPL10):c.482G>A (p.Gly161Asp)

evidence.dc:description: Functional studies in yeast suggest a damaging effect of this variant (Karl et al., 1999, PMID: 9933353)

This variant has been upgraded to 1.5 points because the phenotypes observed in 4 affected males reported by Thevenon et al., 2015 are similar to the phenotypes reported in Brooks et al., 2014 (PMID: 25316788) and Bourque et al., 2018 (PMID: 29066376). Furthermore, the 3 available female mutation carriers exhibited skewed X-inactivation, as observed in the female carriers reported by Brooks et al. (2014).

This variant is supported by functional evidence demonstrating a loss of function in a naturally occurring mutation in yeast affecting the same amino acid (p.Gly161Asp) altered in this family (Karl et al., 1999, PMID: 9933353).

Functional data reported by Brooks et al., 2014 (PMID: 25316788) contradicts the pathogenicity of this missense variant. Additionally, this variant is present in 101/1209747 alleles (0.008%) in gnomAD (v4.1.0), including 21 hemizygous European (non-Finnish) males.

Functional analysis in yeast suggested that this RPL10 missense variant was still able to support basic translation functions but conferred hypomorphism with respect to the regulation of the translation process (Klauck et al., 2006, PMID: 16940977). However, subsequent functional studies performed by Brooks et al. (2014, PMID: 25316788) using in vivo complementation in zebrafish showed that, like wild-type human RPL10 mRNA, the His213Gln variant was able to fully rescue the microcephaly phenotype in morphants.

Score upgraded to 0.5 because of phenotype similarity with previously reported cases and recurrent variant in 3 unrelated individuals. This individual has an older affected brother with the same variant.

This variant was upgraded to 1.5 points because the functional data suggests loss of function. This variant segregates with X-linked syndromic intellectual disability in 3 affected males. Two female mutation carriers exhibited skewed X-inactivation. Variant is absent from gnomAD. This is scored at the top of the range for missense, as this variant was also reported in Bourque et al., 2018 (PMID: 29066376) as de novo in the proband.
Functional data to support this variant's pathogenicity suggests loss of function in a zebrafish complementation assay.
Score upgraded to 0.5 because of phenotype similarity with previously reported cases and recurrent variant in 3 unrelated individuals.

This same variant was reported in a family with 3 affected individuals by Brooks et al., 2014 (PMID: 25316788). The phenotypes are consistent with those reported by Brooks et al. (2014) and Thevenon et al. (2015).
Functional data in zebrafish suggests loss of function.
Next-generation sequencing panel covering 82 genes implicated previously in X-linked ID

member.detectionMethod: X-linked intellectual disability next generation sequencing panel of 82 genes

evidence.dc:description: Score upgraded to 0.5 because of phenotype similarity with previously reported cases and recurrent variant in 3 unrelated individuals.
Phenotype information provided by laboratory via personal communication.

dc:source.dc:abstract: The R3H variant in the RPL10 gene has not been reported previously as a pathogenic variant, nor as a benign variant, to our knowledge. The R3H variant was not observed in approximately 6,500 individuals of European and African American ancestry in the NHLBI Exome Sequencing Project, indicating it is not a common benign variant in these populations. The R3H variant is a conservative amino acid substitution, which is not likely to impact secondary protein structure as these residues share similar properties. This substitution occurs at a position that is conserved across species. Functional studies suggest mutagenesis of the R3 residue reduces the interaction of RPL10 with it's chaperone protein, Sqt1 (Pausch et al., 2015). The R3H variant is a strong candidate for a pathogenic variant
dc:source.dc:creator: GeneDx
dc:source.dc:title: NM_006013.5(RPL10):c.8G>A (p.Arg3His)

evidence.dc:description: The ID/Autism Gene Curation Expert panel decided not to score this experimental evidence because the two variants were later shown not to result in loss of function using in vivo complementation in zebrafish in Brooks et al. (2014, PMID: 25316788).

Two RPL10 variants reported in patients with ASD, p.L206M and p.H213Q, were shown to confer hypomorphism with respect to the regulation of the translation process while keeping the basic translation functions intact. Specifically, the temperature sensitive growth defect of mutant yeast RPL10[p.G161D] at the restrictive temperature is complemented by human WT RPL10 as well as the patient mutant L206M and H213Q alleles.
evidence.rdfs:label: Klauck Functional Alteration in Yeast

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded to be conservative because it is a zebrafish model.

Co-injection of WT human RPL10 mRNA with translation blocking morpholino (tb-MO) resulted in significant improvement of microcephaly phenotype in MO-knockdown zebrafish, while co-injection of the patient variant p.K78E with tb-MO failed to rescue morphant phenotype and resulted in significantly decreased forebrain cross-sectional area. Co-injection with 2 variants reported in ASD, p.H213Q or p.L206M (Klauck et al., 2006, PMID: 16940977), fully rescued the microcephaly phenotype, suggesting that they are not deleterious.
evidence.rdfs:label: Brooks Rescue in Zebrafish

evidence.dc:description: Downgraded because it is a zebrafish model and because it uses a morpholino-induced knockdown.

Knockdown of rpl10 in zebrafish with a translation blocking morpholino resulted in a significant decrease in head size, similar to microcephaly seen in humans. Morphant anterior structures showed increase in 80S ribosome abundance and decrease in polyribosomes. Posterior portions of morphant larvae were relatively unchanged. Additionally, there was a six-fold increase in cell death in forebrain of rpl10 morphants compared to controls. This suggests apoptosis as a mechanism of microcephaly.
evidence.rdfs:label: Brooks Zebrafish Model
